#Text=CHAPTER XVI .
#Text=IN WHICH I TURN SMUGGLER , AND THE CAPTAIN CASUIST

#Text=The last night at Midway , I had little sleep ; the next morning , after the sun was risen , and the clatter of departure had begun to reign on deck , I lay a long while dozing ; and when at last I stepped from the companion , the schooner was already leaping through the pass into the open sea .
#Text=Close on her board , the huge scroll of a breaker unfurled itself along the reef with a prodigious clamour ; and behind I saw the wreck vomiting into the morning air a coil of smoke .
#Text=The wreaths already blew out far to leeward , flames already glittered in the cabin skylight ; and the sea-fowl were scattered in surprise as wide as the lagoon .

#Text=As we drew farther off , the conflagration of the Flying Scud flamed higher ; and long after we had dropped all signs of Midway Island , the smoke still hung in the horizon like that of a distant steamer .

#Text=With the fading out of that last vestige , the Norah Creina , passed again into the empty world of cloud and water by which she had approached ; and the next features that appeared , eleven days later , to break the line of sky , were the arid mountains of Oahu .

#Text=It has often since been a comfortable thought to me that we had thus destroyed the tell-tale remnants of the Flying Scud ; and often a strange one that my last sight and reminiscence of that fatal ship should be a pillar of smoke on the horizon .

#Text=To so many others besides myself the same appearance had played a part in the various stages of that business : luring some to what they little imagined , filling some with unimaginable terrors .
#Text=But ours was the last smoke raised in the story ; and with its dying away the secret of the Flying Scud became a private property .
#Text=It was by the first light of dawn that we saw , close on board , the metropolitan island of Hawaii .

#Text=We held along the coast , as near as we could venture , with a fresh breeze and under an unclouded heaven ; beholding , as we went , the arid mountain sides and scrubby cocoa-palms of that somewhat melancholy archipelago .

#Text=About four of the afternoon we turned Waimanolo Point , the westerly headland of the great bight of Honolulu ; showed ourselves for twenty minutes in full view ; and then fell again to leeward , and put in the rest of daylight , plying under shortened sail under the lee of Waimanolo .
#Text=A little after dark we beat once more about the point , and crept cautiously toward the mouth of the Pearl Lochs , where Jim and I had arranged I was to meet the smugglers .
#Text=The night was happily obscure , the water smooth .
#Text=We showed , according to instructions , no light on deck : only a red lantern dropped from either cathead to within a couple of feet of the water .
#Text=A lookout was stationed on the bowsprit end , another in the crosstrees ; and the whole ship 's company crowded forward , scouting for enemies or friends .

#Text=It was now the crucial moment of our enterprise ; we were now risking liberty and credit ; and that for a sum so small to a man in my bankrupt situation , that I could have laughed aloud in bitterness .
#Text=But the piece had been arranged , and we must play it to the finish .

#Text=For some while , we saw nothing but the dark mountain outline of the island , the torches of native fishermen glittering here and there along the foreshore , and right in the midst that cluster of brave lights with which the town of Honolulu advertises itself to the seaward .
#Text=Presently a ruddy star appeared inshore of us , and seemed to draw near unsteadily .
#Text=This was the anticipated signal ; and we made haste to show the countersign , lowering a white light from the quarter , extinguishing the two others , and laying the schooner incontinently to .
#Text=The star approached slowly ; the sounds of oars and of men 's speech came to us across the water ; and then a voice hailed us .
#Text=“ Is that Mr. Dodd ? ”
#Text=“ Yes , ” I returned .
#Text=“ Is Jim Pinkerton there ? ”
#Text=“ No , sir , ” replied the voice .
#Text=“ But there 's one of his crowd here ; name of Speedy . ”
#Text=“ I 'm here , Mr. Dodd , ” added Speedy himself .
#Text=“ I have letters for you . ”
#Text=“ All right , ” I replied .
#Text=“ Come aboard , gentlemen , and let me see my mail . ”

#Text=A whaleboat accordingly ranged alongside , and three men boarded us : my old San Francisco friend , the stock-gambler Speedy , a little wizened person of the name of Sharpe , and a big , flourishing , dissipated-looking man called Fowler .

#Text=The two last ( I learned afterward ) were frequent partners ; Sharpe supplied the capital , and Fowler , who was quite a character in the islands and occupied a considerable station , brought activity , daring , and a private influence , highly necessary in the case .
#Text=Both seemed to approach the business with a keen sense of romance ; and I believe this was the chief attraction , at least with Fowler -- for whom I early conceived a sentiment of liking .
#Text=But in that first moment I had something else to think of than to judge my new acquaintances ; and before Speedy had fished out the letters , the full extent of our misfortune was revealed .
#Text=“ We 've rather bad news for you , Mr. Dodd , ” said Fowler .
#Text=“ Your firm 's gone up . ”
